segments.text: All yours.
All right.
Well, my name's Skip Porter.
In the birth records, you'll see Wilbur Arthur.
I saw that somewhere.
Who is that?
So some time ago, we standardized on W. Arthur for kind of the formal.
But most people that know me call me Skip.
Born in Texas.
Born in Irving, Texas.
Grew up in the state, educated here at North Texas State, bachelor's and master's in physics there, and then did a PhD work at Texas A&M in lunch engineering or interdisciplinary engineering.
Worked in the R&D labs of Texas Instruments.
In Dallas?
In Dallas.
In Dallas.
In the mid-60s, back during the first large-scale integration, first LSI days of the integrated circuit world.
Those were exciting times, I guess.
Uh-huh, they were.
And Texas A&M was interested in establishing a microelectronics program and asked me to do that, and I took a leave of absence from the R&D labs at Texas Instruments.
Who had you worked in with in EE at A&M?
I worked closely with, well at the time we got him Bill Jones.
I know Bill very well.
Was the department head.
And John Linder was on the faculty at that time, and Albert Druce.
Then all the kind of young guys, so to speak, that came in at once.
We got him Roland Hayden and Jack Stone.
and John Linder and myself.
They were kind of the four solid state electronic guys.
So I did that.
I worked, and actually I came back to Texas A&M in 1968 on leave to finish up my PhD.
I'd come to Texas A&M in 64 from North Texas.
with a master's in physics, and it started on my PhD in physics at Texas A&M.
I was there for two years teaching in math and physics as an instructor while I did my PhD work.
And I finished my coursework and kind of ran out of gas for going to school.
That happens.
Yeah.
And so I left Texas A&M in 66.
June of 66.
I always remember my starting date, Texas Instruments was 6-6-66.
Is that right?
That's good.
That's an easy way to remember, yeah.
And so, you know, I had been toying with various ways to finish my PhD, either at SMU or North Texas, and then went A&M.
asked that I come to the EE department to help start up this microelectronics program.
I agreed to do that, took a leave from TI, went back to Texas A&M on the EE faculty as an assistant professor, and took a technician that had been working with me at Texas Instruments.
And we started actually physically building in the old Bolton Hall, Texas A&M's first
facility to do research in semiconductor device fabrication.
High technology.
High technology.
Comes to Aggieland.
Yeah.
That's interesting.
And so I put that laboratory together.
I'm sure physically you did it.
Oh, I built it.
I mean, you had to build it.
Literally, yeah.
Al Drewson.
along with Leonard Dollarhide, who was the technician.
Did you get support from Texas Instruments?
No, this was $50,000 that TEAS, the Texas Engineering Experiment Station, which I ended up later directing, had put into the EE department.
And actually, how it came up, curiously enough, was I was on campus recruiting for Texas Instruments.
And Bill Jones called over to the recruiting office
And when he learned that Texas Instruments was there recruiting, asking if anybody was there that could advise the EE department on how to spend this $50,000.
And so I was asked.
And I said, sure, I'll go over and talk to them.
And so I went over.
And at the end of the day, we went to dinner.
And Jones and Drews asked me if I'd be willing to come on the faculty.
So that's how it happened.
And I told them no, I wasn't interested.
appreciated the invitation, but I was on a pretty exciting project at TI, which was the continuous diffusion program.
I was working then with Jack Kilby.
Oh, so that was, okay.
That's how Jack and I met.
Jack was the director of the labs.
I've always wondered how that happened.
Well, he was the director of the labs, and we had this idea that if it was a great world, we could pour a bag of sand into a funnel and not touch anything and integrate circuits with
I'll pop out the other end.
And so my job was to design that system.

And I was right in the middle of that and had actually applied for the patent on what we call the continuous diffusion system, which was the basis for the TI automated system for bill and aggregate circuits.
But in a few weeks, maybe a few months, incubating that idea,
It was something I knew I could help Texas A&M with.
It provided a very concurrent, comfortable way for me to finish up my PhD.
It required that I shift from physics to engineering, which was not a hard shift for me to make because I was kind of in device physics anyway.
Texas A&M didn't really have a
an applied physics degree.
So what I did do was go into what was called, and still is as far as I know, if it still exists, the interdisciplinary engineering.
And so my PhD is in interdisciplinary engineering.
It's kind of a mastered combination of physics, math, chemistry, chemical engineering, mechanical engineering, and double E. And I had written a proposal to NASA
for support for a research contract in the applications of space for semiconductor device manufacturing.
And in 70, when I pretty much had the laboratory together and had completed my PhD, I was interviewing with TI and with several other companies.
So I was still on leave.
And I got this contract, this research contract from Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama.
So A&M was most interested in me staying because it was a nice contract for the university to have.
So you had to apply independently for that?
Yeah.
I'd just written the proposal.
I was the principal investigator, and I'd just sent it in as a faculty member.
I was in unusual circumstances.
I was an assistant professor, but I was also a graduate student.
I was finishing my PhD.
But I wrote the proposal, sent it in, and got it.
And that was 1970, which was a really tough time in the industry.
TI was most pleased for me to continue to stay on leave.
from TI, maintain the link with me at Texas A&M, but have me be an A&M employee.
And I did that, and probably until the mid-70s before we finally, I finally said it.
I didn't realize you had a big, long TI connection.
Yeah.
And I still do consulting work for TI up until that time off and on.
And then we got some TI, sporadic and small as it was, support for the labs at A&M.
So that was kind of the early 70s, and I maintained continuous support from NASA in the program they called Processing in Space Reuse on Earth.
There were two of us in the country early on, a guy named Harry Gatiss, who was a professor at MIT,
And Harry was looking at how to grow crystals.
And I was looking at how to process silicon, the advantages of low gravity, the thermal environment with full thermal conductivity and radiation.
So at any rate, that semiconductor device research
support continued from NASA at A&M for quite a while, and that expanded in other areas.
We got other contracts.

I had a contract with the Rome Air Development Center Air Force support for similar kinds of defect analysis, and we were looking a lot at process-induced defects in silicon and their impact on the yield of integrated circuits.
Now, are you doing any teaching at this time?
Oh yeah, I'm full-time.
Full-time teaching.
I'm teaching big-time, heavy-duty state of Texas loads, like nine hours.
In physics or engineering?
No, in electrical engineering.
In electrical engineering.
Well, and in mechanical engineering.
So we changed.
It was a funny occurrence because, of course, I had been teaching both physics and math at A&M from 64 to 66.
And then I was at TI from 66 to 68, and then I was back at Texas A&M in 68.

And somewhere in the early 70s, I guess it was, or maybe it was in the late 60s, we switched because of all the complaining by the engineering students about how tough physics was and how many people were flunking, so that they could take mechanical engineering instead of physics.
And then the M.E.
department didn't have enough professors to teach the M.E.
courses.
So I got loaned to M.E.
to teach M.E.
for a while.
So I taught a lot, a lot of different classes.
And then I remember it really upset, what was the guy's name that was...
In M.E.?
Uh-huh.
Not McDonald.
No, he was the C.A.
No, it was way before McDonald, though.
He was an old Army guy, Simons or Bob...
Crawford, no?
Crawford was nuclear.
I can't remember his name either.
Bob's his first name.
I'm sure he was a big, burly guy.
But I flunked half of the ME class in that course, and that wasn't traditional over there either.
Well, I used to teach physics.
We got these kids that got up for farm.
So that didn't turn out to help out much, but at any rate,
So, yeah, I was teaching full-time, usually one or two graduate courses and or undergraduate courses.
But having really focused on research, you were really good.
Well, yeah, and then we established in the early 70s, somewhere, you have to go back to A&M for this history, the Institute for Solid State Electronics.
And the first director was a guy named Roland Haight.
And Roland headed up this institute, which the faculty members were the guys I mentioned earlier, Stone and Hayden and Linder and myself and Drush.
And this faculty formed the members of the institute, which was a subset of the EE department.
really had the responsibility for building the research programs and the laboratories.
It was about in that period where we started designing the new engineering building, what's now the Zachry Engineering Center.
Hayden left to take the chairmanship of EE, I think, at OU.
and I was asked to become the director of the Institute for Solid State Electronics.

And the new building, Fred Benson was dean of engineering then, and Fred asked me to come up with what we thought we could use facility-wise in the Zachry building, and so we designed the institute there.
And so when we moved out of old Bolton Hall,

into the new Zachary Center, we ended up with quite a first-class facility for the Institute for South State Electronics, and I brought in some other faculty members, Don Parker, and John Ignorian, and Raghav Pandey, and we began to build the faculty and the graduate students, and grew the center, the Institute,
I guess at that time about a million dollars a year.
And they're heavily research again, rather than teaching.
You're getting into a real research complex.
We're creating a strong effort in developing a strong graduate research program, an academic research environment, of course.
A&M is just now going into that whole moment.
That's right.
And that was the challenge and the theme for A&M to try to become a major research university.
So that moves us into about mid-70s.
And it was in there that Kilby and I started.
This was during the energy crisis, during the Carter days, during the long gas lines.
And so we started a project to develop a new type of photovoltaic solar cell.
And Kilby and I, a former colleague
the labs at DI, Jay Lathrop, who's now gone as professor of electrical engineering at Clemson.
But Jack and Jay and I started working on a new idea for a spherical solar cell, which we developed in the institute at A&M and patented.
And Texas Instruments, who had retained a right of first refusal
such projects that Jack backed.
Jack had since left EI.
He was operating as an independent inventor.
But Jack and I had maintained our contacts and because we had this capability in the labs of the Institute at A&M, Jack and I started working, you know, we pulled out all the corks on this project.
He's physically at A&M.
No, he lives in Dallas, but he's coming, driving back and forth from Dallas to College Station.
And gets a pretty good introduction to the university and the life of the people, and we gain a renewed professional interaction together.
And we are successful at getting a $14 million DOE contract to support this work when we transfer it to TI.
So that kind of re-establishes now, although I'm no longer on leave of absence from TI, it kind of re-establishes my contact back with TI through this project.
And so then I start consulting again pretty heavily for TI in moving the technology from Texas A&M to the labs in Dallas at Texas Instruments.
And several of the graduate students that I had working for me then become TI employees.
And so that link, a guy named Randy McKee I think is still there, was one of my top graduate students at A&M, and worked closely with Jack and me when this project was in its formative stages at A&M.
That's a good story, the transfusion between academia and industry.
Well, and it's relevant to HARC.
Because I have always personally
been a strong believer that those two separate entities in our society could benefit far more from one another if they took the time to figure out how to work together.
But the historical and traditional attitude in its fundamental sense
In industry, that's an academic, I retire a bunch, stay away from them.
In the academic community, that's those money, grubby, profit guys, stay away from them.
And so it's very difficult to find a way to link the two, yet on an individual basis.
I was intrigued.
I very much enjoyed my experience at Texas Instruments.
I very much enjoyed my experience at Texas A&M.
clearly saw advantages to both if they could work together.

And I had, just as an aside, but on a personal level, to the extent that that's interesting in this talk and this discussion, I had begun to consult for a little company in Portland, Oregon called Electro Scientific Industries, which was quite a small $5 million a year operation building laser systems to trim thin film resistors.
These are resistors that are printed on a ceramic, and then you go in and trim the printed resistor to value.
By shaving it off, you can increase the resistance.
So they would trim it, cut it with a laser, and monitor the resistance and get it to just the value they wanted.
And they were trying to expand their product line to get into the integrated circuit industry out of the hybrid industry only.
And I ended up starting to consult for them while I was a professor at Texas A&M.
This was a company way up in Portland, Oregon.
They approached me at a conference in New York City where I'd given a paper on semiconductor device physics and the process of building integrated circuits.
And as a result of that, we went to NSL to apply for support through the old RAND program.
You may remember Research Applied to National Need.
Tried to get support because that was designed for a small business to link with an academic research university to help develop a new product.
But today, the bottom line is I'm chairman of the board of that company.
And the company has grown to some $80 million a year and has market share worldwide on a laser system used to build a DRAM memory chip.
And Jack Kilby is now also on the board of that company.
So it's a small world.
They come together and we keep the players.
But that's just another example.
The reason I mention that is that's a university-industry link that demonstrates the ability to make it work, that it can work.
And so it was my hope for Texas A&M, A&M being what I believed the most aggressive major research institution in the state,
in terms of seeking interaction with the pipe sector.
A&M had much more of the image and tradition of having grease under their fingernails.
This was the nuts and bolts of engineers.
Roll up your sleeves, wait in there, and get it done kind of attitude.
Well, that's what these NASA engineers talk about, hands-on engineering.
Hands-on engineering.
A&M drifted away from that some.
We decided in some
piece of the history that followed that we needed to look more like Harvard than MIT.

But during the days when all of this was coming together, in engineering at least, this was while Fred Benson was dean, this work with Texas Instruments and Electro-Scientific Industries was very much positive and well received.
That went on up through the 70s.

I remained as a professor of electrical engineering, developing the research program, publishing hot and heavy, building a larger institute team of faculty and graduate students and chasing the support for the research grants.
in order to establish Texas A&M's Institute for Solid State Electronics as a major national research facility in microelectronics.
And in 1979, I was asked to take the directorship of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
By Benson?
By Benson, by Fred Benson.
This was a tumultuous time, Henry, at A&M, as you'll recall.
There was big changes on the horizon in the structure of the system and the presidency of the university.
And I've been completely insulated.
As most of the faculty, you're oblivious to all of that.
You barely know who's president, and it's really not so important.
You kind of live in your own world.
You do your own thing.
And my life was exciting and full.
At about that time, the toughest decision was to decide which invited lecture to accept and which trip to go on.
And the biggest challenge was keeping the contractual dollars flowing into a growing research institute.
But I had been asked the year before by Fred Benson again to take the presidency of the Texas A&M Research Foundation.
And I had turned that down.
I had not been interested in that.
Why did he ask you?
Was that when he was?
Yeah, he was.
When did he become the head of that?
He had been.
He started it, didn't he?
Yeah, he started it.
He started it while he was director of the Engineering Experiment Station.
Oh, I didn't realize it.
And then he was kind of...
He wore both hats.
Oh, absolutely.
And Fred was also, if not the chairman of the board of the Research Foundation, was kind of the godfather of guiding it.
And I don't know what influence he had, but
I know when I was asked to take it, it wasn't, would you consider being a candidate?
I mean, she just walked in my office and said, we'd like to make you president of the foundation, and I'd like for you to think about it.
And I did, and told him I wasn't interested.
So I turned that down the year before, and then he came in and called me down.
It was off, and he said, okay, Porter, we want to make you director of the Texas Indian Experimental Station.
And my first reaction was, well, I'm not interested in that.
I mean, I'm doing what I want to do, and I've kind of hit a stride here.
It's getting easier to do what I want to do, and it's expanding, and we really are building and growing in reputation worldwide.
But he was persistent, and I thought, all right, I need to think about this.
And I was leaving for China.
I had been invited with nine other double E's from kind of all over the country to go on an early mission.
This was September of 79.
And we were going to be gone a month, traveling all over the PRC.
And Benson told me I had to give him my decision before I left.
He hadn't had the decision by the beginning of the academic year, and this was about mid-August when he called me in, so I had a couple weeks to think about it.

And a guy named Bob Page had just been brought in as dean of engineering, and I had no idea this was a request by Fred, and I asked him, and Jarvis Miller was president of the university, and Frank Hubert
was in as chancellor.
Well, that wasn't interim period.
So I went over to see Jarvis.
Well, first thing I did was ask Fred who else he had talked to, and he said nobody, that he wanted to know how I felt about it.
I said, well, I'll think about it, but I guess I feel like we need to find out how Jarvis, well, particularly Jarvis and Bob Page.
And so Fred just called Bob Bates down to his office.
Fred was then deputy chancellor for engineering.
We went through a lot of different structures during this time trying to figure out how to run the place.
Bob and I went to lunch following that, and I told him, I said, look, you're the new dean here.
This is it.

before I even want to consider this appointment, I'd like for this to be something that you feel like makes sense, and you don't know me from Adam, why don't you go check me out, and after you've had some time to do that, give me a call.
And he called back in, I think it was the next day, or probably maybe two days at most, but I believe it was the next day, and said, you know, let's do this.
If you're willing to do it, let's do it.
So I got another stop or two to make, so then I went over to see Jarvis.
Jarvis.
felt the same way.
He knew what it was all about.
Oh yeah, he'd been director of takes.
But between, and I'm not going to go into all that in this, it's probably ought to be written down somewhere and sealed, but between that moment and the actual
transition to where I took the directorship was a pretty interesting time.
Actually, I guess at that moment, Frank Hubert was not, at that specific moment, Frank Hubert had not been asked to come in as interim chancellor.
It was just in advance of that.
Because I went off to China, having agreed that I would accept the directorship.
which Fred promptly announced to the entire faculty while I was gone.
And so when I returned to campus, I was greeted by my colleagues with great response to this announcement.
And then the system went apart.
The university at the moment, at that moment when I agreed to do that,
the agencies reported to the university president, which Jarvis had gotten the board to agree to change from reporting to the system.
And when Jarvis finally was in, when Jarvis finally transitioned out of the presidency, the system was reorganized.
Hubert was chancellor

And the system went back to the mode in which it had been, where then all of the agencies were autonomously managed along with the universities in the system, and did not report to the board through the president, but through the chancellor.
And so I went through a little interesting period of meeting Frank and discussing all of this.
And finally it got out to the point where I told all of them I wasn't interested in the job.
But the bottom line was it finally did happen in March.
And so from 1980 through for the five years from 1980 through 1984, I was director of the Texas Indian Experiment Station.
If you had a philosophy as director of the Experiment Station,
I was interested.
I went back and read the original legislation of 1914 that created the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
And the comments from previous directors, the first one was a guy named Spence, as I recall.
And in point of fact, the Texas Engineering Experimental Station had never really functioned as a state agency like the Texas... Well, it functioned as if it was, but it was not.
It was a state agency created by an act of the legislature, and the director had
fiduciary responsibility for taxpayers' money and got the money directly from the legislature, just like that.
But they didn't get much money, as I recall.
No, they didn't.
But we changed that.
We turned that around, which was one of my objectives and one of my challenges.
And what I was asked by the Board of Regents to do was to turn TEAS into a true state agency and to branch it out statewide and to have it work for Texas
all the way across the state, like the Agricultural Experiment Station.
And to make it something different than a research instrument of the College of Engineering of Texas A&M University only.
And as a faculty member of Texas A&M, a professor of electrical engineering, I walked down to the Texas Engineering Experiment Station office
And the dean of the College of Engineering of Texas A&M University was also the director of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station, so you couldn't tell the difference.
And the resources of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station were predominantly used, if not totally used, by a faculty of Texas A&M University in the College of Engineering.
So that was my tradition, my expectation, my experience.
When in September, after talking to Paige and Miller, I agreed to take the job.
When in March, I was put into the position, I was then reporting to the board through the chancellor.
And the board and the chancellor said, Porter,
turn this into a bona fide state agency that can serve the state.
And as that began to happen, and it did, we did it.
It created some serious consternation on the campus of Texas A&M.
But we opened divisions of the Engineering Experiment Station at UT Arlington.
at Lamar University, at Prairie View A&M University, at the specific request of von Breit to try to help that institution gain some breadth.
And at the time I left, I was in very substantive discussion with Peter Flon and Jerry Fonkin.
about the possibility of T's operating the balconies in Austin, which would have been a UT-Austin-Texas A&M connection that I think would have been extremely healthy for the state.
But back at the ranch, meantime, I had also established the education technology division to help
the College of Education at Texas A&M University to develop a research program.
I had to establish the business technology division to do the same thing with the college business.
Bill Muse and then Bill Mobley headed those two divisions up.
And we went from zero funded dollars in the college of business to a million dollars pretty quickly.
So TEAS was beginning to branch out, as I had been asked to make it do.
And our state revenue went from what had been $1 million a year to $6 million a year from the state.
And we were turning that in leveraging outside contract dollars into a total operational budget in excess of $30 million.
I learned a lot.
about the politics of Texas, about the politics of higher education, about the politics of Texas A&M, and state agencies.
What about private business cooperation?
Was there much of that kind of activity?
Yes, and that was one of the real leverages of TEAS for particularly Texas A&M, was it was a place, because it was a separate agency, it wasn't a line item
in the university budget.
It was its own budget.
And it had some leveraged advantages for the university that a lot of the colleges were seeing how to take advantage of.
One of the problems has been historically, and always will be historically, the issue is one of control.
It's who's running the place, the system or the university or the agency.
Sure.
And it always will.
And it's why chancellors and presidents have a hard time getting along.

And unless chancellors, in my judgment, can rise to the level of kind of statesmen, national and international statesmanship, to speak to the larger issue philosophically of the needs of higher education and can pontificate those points at the national and international level representing

a state and a system within the state's views rather than worrying about which classes are being taught on campus and leave that to the administrative operation and the president of that campus and rise up to another level.
The greatest conflict occurs within our educational systems when everybody wants to be sure they're in charge of the football coach or the curriculum.
But in the case, as I see it still today, and as I saw it then, in the case of the Engineering Experiment Station, we had the advantage of being able to focus on research and move aggressively.
As an institution, we were not encumbered with teaching responsibilities.
And we had the resources.
We got the money.
from the legislature directly and had full authority independent of any other entity on what to do with those resources.
Including the board of A&M?
Oh, no.
The board approved the budget.
Right.
But the board was given legislative authority

So once the board approved your budget, that was before the fact because you didn't go to the legislature to argue your budget until the board had reviewed what you asked for or what you were planning to ask for.
So by the time the session was over and the money was appropriated, the authority was already there.

And in the case of the state agencies, particularly the ag experience station and the engineering experience station, it had some unusual advantages, maybe unique advantages, because it got to keep all its own indirect costs.
Because in essence, we were the, let me rephrase that, the university was the reluctant landlord of the agencies.
Because where that coupling occurred was the facilities and the buildings in which these agencies operated were budgeted.
The facilities were budgeted through the university.
And if you put yourself in the position of the president of the university or, say, the vice president for research,
They didn't have near the authority or the power, that is the resources, the dollars, to build a research program that those two agencies did.
And so from their perspective, the tail was wagging the dog.
And it's an understandable one.
Yet when you put yourself in the position of the director of the agency, that's his job.
That's right.
And you may, well, yeah, and your boss is the same boss as the president of the university.

And when the entire board of regents stands in unison and applauds what you're doing, and the other guy is getting his, and he's saying, hmm, I don't think I like this a whole lot, and it can create and did and still does and always will.
I don't think it's a matter of personality.
It's a matter of drawing the lines on the diagram.
We, I think, waded through a lot of the awkwardness of that fairly well, just working through personal relationships.
But it was such a tumultuous period within the A&M system.
The whole world, yeah.
The turmoil, yeah.
I really grew quite bored with it.
And then the chancellor changed.
Art Hanson came in.
then the dean changed.

It was, and this was part of the period when A&M, in my judgment, was trying to create a different kind of scholarly image for itself, which I didn't particularly, well, I didn't like and still don't.
I think it was a big time mistake.
But, so be it.
That's life.
So, that's
The 80 to 85 period, you asked the question about industry.
We worked closely with like the Ford Motor Company.
I remember one interesting call I got.
You may remember the period when Ford had the problem with their automatic transmissions jumping out of reverse.
Yeah.
I got a call from the vice president of research at Ford, and he wanted to know if we could
do an analysis on the hydraulic transmission.
And I immediately knew why he was calling.
I said, sure, we could.
I said, does this have to do with your transmission jumping out of reverse?
Well, yes, as a matter of fact, it does.
And we've got a testimony before the Senate hearing in 30 days.
And we'd like to have an independent assessment.
And I thought, oh, boy, that could really be a political hot potato.
But we had the talent that could evaluate.
And the more I thought about that, I decided this was the occasion where we needed to do a public service.
So I told him.
I said, yeah, we'll do it under two conditions.
The first one is obvious, but I just stated that we'll tell you whatever we find.
And the second is we'll accept no payment.
What did he say then?
Well, he agreed to it.
We did it.
And I don't recall what the results were.
But I wanted to be sure he fully understood that our opinion wasn't for sale.
And B, furthermore, that I didn't want to subject Texas A&M to even the scrutiny that we had sold an opinion, regardless of what it was, so that we'd do this as a public service for free.
You have to.
I'm glad you thought of that.
Well, but then we did a lot of work for them.
And we did work for TI.
We did work for Boeing.
We did work for Shell.
We did work for, I mean, I'm just grabbing names now, a cross section of industries.
And that was the engineering, that was the concept
of the legislature, which isn't a one-to-one analogy with the agricultural industry.
The agrarian society was very different and continues to be.
Parity doesn't exist in the automotive or the electronics industry like it does in the corn industry or the cotton or cattle.
Competitive.
Yeah.
But let me mention one other thing that may be relevant to the Hark story.
Of course, I personally had come out of industry.
Yeah, you know, I was thinking about everything you've been telling me.
Had you not had that several years' experience at TI, I think your perspective of the world and your knowledge of the world may have been substantially different.
Oh, very substantially different, no question about it.
And my continuing work in relationship with electroscientific industries was a very educational period for me.
In having home base in the academic community in America,
but taking full advantage of the academic policy of giving your professors one day a week to go off and do consulting and maintaining my ties back to corporate America and my involvement.
At this point in time, the 80 to 85 period, I went on the board of directors of electroscientific industries.
I began to function not only as a consultant, but as a director of a corporation, a high-tech corp in this country.
So the first time you're really getting a broad profile of industry.
Yeah, and I'm beginning to gain an understanding.
We took this company from a privately, very closely held company.
We took it public.
So I got the full-blown experience as a board member of going through a...
an initial public offering of a privately held company, a good bath in the Securities and Exchange Commission regulation and all of the aspects of what that involves.
So I'm gaining during this period an awful lot of experience in business as well as academic, as well as state politics.
In 1980, when I took over the directorship of the experiment station,

Well, I was a greenhorn professor with a little bit of industry experience and having demonstrated an ability to pull together an institute with a group of faculty and begin to attract federal R&D dollars.
But I had never walked on the floor of the House or the Senate and argued before a committee a budget for a state agency, which is what I had to do.
And it was a budget I had not put together.
It was a budget that Fred had put together.
But they just handed me the budget and said,
Here's when the legislature meets.
This is when your session is.
Good luck, son.
So it was a great experience.

So I began to learn the political process, the budgeting process, how to deal with the legislature, how a budget for a state budget was put together, how a university or a system budget was put together.
